Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language is used to develop relationships in formal and informal situations
Elaboration: Recognising that language is adjusted in different contexts, for example in degree of formality when moving between group discussions and presenting a group report

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language is used to develop relationships in formal and informal situations
Elaboration: Understanding how age, expertise and familiarity influence the ways in which people interact and how these codes and conventions vary across cultures

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language is used to develop relationships in formal and informal situations
Elaboration: Recognising the importance of using inclusive language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language is used to develop relationships in formal and informal situations
Elaboration: Exploring cultural respect for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Elders and greeting conventions between Victorian Aboriginal Peoples

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and differentiate the language of opinion, facts and feelings
Elaboration: Identifying ways that ‘thinking’ verbs are used to express opinions (for example, ‘I think’ or ‘I believe’) and ways that ‘summary’ verbs are used to report findings (for example, ‘we concluded’)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and differentiate the language of opinion, facts and feelings
Elaboration: Comparing statements that have similar information presented through facts and opinion, for example ‘The man has 6 cats.’ and ‘The man has too many noisy cats.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how different types of texts across the curriculum have different language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying the typical stages and language features of texts such as narratives, factual recounts, imaginative recounts, biographies, information reports, explanations, book talks, poetry and arguments for a particular purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how different types of texts across the curriculum have different language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages depending on purposes
Elaboration: Understanding how and why text structure is important in texts such as sequential and causal explanations, and comparative and part-whole information reports

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how different types of texts across the curriculum have different language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages depending on purposes
Elaboration: Recognising that poems have different purposes that influence the organisation of the text into characteristic stages, for example poems that tell stories, poems that describe and poems that reflect on aspects of life

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how different types of texts across the curriculum have different language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages depending on purposes
Elaboration: Recognising the difference between a text’s form (such as a poster, email or list) and its organisation into stages, depending on its social purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how text connectives, including temporal and conditional words, and topic word associations, are used to sequence and connect ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how authors construct texts that are cohesive and coherent using pronouns that link to something previously mentioned and determiners (for example, ‘this’, ‘that’, ‘these’ and ‘those’) to identify things

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how text connectives, including temporal and conditional words, and topic word associations, are used to sequence and connect ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how authors use text connectives to create links between sentences, for example ‘however’, ‘therefore’, ‘nevertheless’ and ‘in addition’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how text connectives, including temporal and conditional words, and topic word associations, are used to sequence and connect ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how text connectives link sections of a text, providing sequences through time, for example ‘firstly’, ‘then’, ‘next’ and ‘finally’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify navigation features of digital texts that enhance readability, including headlines, drop-down menus, links, graphics and layout
Elaboration: Investigating the features used for texts (such as headings and subheadings in print text, and home pages and subpages in digital texts) and how these help the reader to select text for a purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify navigation features of digital texts that enhance readability, including headlines, drop-down menus, links, graphics and layout
Elaboration: Comparing the features of texts on similar topics online

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that complex sentences contain one independent clause and at least one dependent clause typically joined by a subordinating conjunction to create relationships, such as time and causality
Elaboration: Creating richer, more specific descriptions by using adjectival clauses; for example, ‘Crossing the mountain range was difficult.’ becomes ‘The mountain pass was dangerous when it rained.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that complex sentences contain one independent clause and at least one dependent clause typically joined by a subordinating conjunction to create relationships, such as time and causality
Elaboration: Creating more precise and detailed sentences by adding adverbial clauses; for example, ‘They crossed the mountain range.’ becomes ‘Although the path was overgrown, they crossed the mountain range.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how adverb groups or phrases and prepositional phrases work in different ways to provide circumstantial details about an activity
Elaboration: Investigating in texts how adverb groups/phrases and prepositional phrases can provide details of the circumstances surrounding a happening or state, for example ‘At midnight (time) he rose slowly (manner) from the chair (place) and went upstairs (place).’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand past, present and future tenses and their impact on meaning in a sentence
Elaboration: Understanding the tense that types of texts are commonly written in; for example, informative texts are usually written in present tense

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand past, present and future tenses and their impact on meaning in a sentence
Elaboration: Identifying the tense in texts they read

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Explore how the use of sound and choices in the framing of an image, the placement of elements in the image, and the salience in the image affect the composition of still and moving images and enhance the meaning of a text
Elaboration: Examining visual and multimodal texts, building a vocabulary to describe visual elements and techniques such as framing, composition and salience, and beginning to understand how these choices influence viewer response

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Explore how the use of sound and choices in the framing of an image, the placement of elements in the image, and the salience in the image affect the composition of still and moving images and enhance the meaning of a text
Elaboration: Identifying the angle at which the camera is pointed at a subject and discussing how the angle influences meaning

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Expand vocabulary by exploring a range of synonyms and antonyms, and using words encountered in a range of sources
Elaboration: Building vocabulary from research about technical and learning area–specific topics, for example gravity and magnetic forces

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Expand vocabulary by exploring a range of synonyms and antonyms, and using words encountered in a range of sources
Elaboration: Determining or clarifying the shades of meaning of synonyms and antonyms

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Expand vocabulary by exploring a range of synonyms and antonyms, and using words encountered in a range of sources
Elaboration: Using words encountered in texts that are formed from an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander language, for example the Shire of Nillumbik, which draws its name from the Wurundjeri name for the region, meaning 'shallow earth'

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that punctuation signals dialogue through quotation marks and that dialogue follows conventions for the use of capital letters, commas and boundary punctuation
Elaboration: Identifying the use of quotation marks, capital letters, commas and boundary punctuation to signal dialogue in texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that punctuation signals dialogue through quotation marks and that dialogue follows conventions for the use of capital letters, commas and boundary punctuation
Elaboration: Using punctuated dialogue in their own writing

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Explore how quoted (direct) and reported (indirect) speech are used
Elaboration: Investigating examples of quoted (direct) speech (for example, ‘He said, “I’ll go to the park today.”’) and reported (indirect) speech (for example, ‘He told me he was going to the park today.’) and why they have been used in different contexts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise similar storylines, ideas and relationships in different contexts in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Comparing the plots and characters in 2 literary texts with similar ideas (for example, 2 literary texts that explore friendship) by a wide range of Australian authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise similar storylines, ideas and relationships in different contexts in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Commenting on how literary texts set in different time periods present ideas about nature

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise similar storylines, ideas and relationships in different contexts in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Discussing how everyday life, such as mealtimes and family relationships, is depicted in particular historical and cultural contexts in texts by a wide range of world authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise similar storylines, ideas and relationships in different contexts in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Recognising similar storylines and ideas in literature by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Describe the effects of text structures and language features in a range of literary texts when responding to and sharing opinions
Elaboration: Sharing and discussing their understanding of the effects of literary techniques on their appreciation of texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Describe the effects of text structures and language features in a range of literary texts when responding to and sharing opinions
Elaboration: Sharing responses to texts, using appropriate language to talk specifically about grammar and literature, for example ‘The use of the noun groups to describe the character really helps to create images for the reader.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Describe the effects of text structures and language features in a range of literary texts when responding to and sharing opinions
Elaboration: Using language appropriate for a text, such as ‘flashback’, ‘tension’ and ‘resolution’, when sharing opinions about plot structure

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Compare how authors and illustrators make literary texts exciting, moving and absorbing and hold readers’ interest by using plot tension, character and setting
Elaboration: Examining an author’s choice of language to describe a character’s appearance, behaviour and speech

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Compare how authors and illustrators make literary texts exciting, moving and absorbing and hold readers’ interest by using plot tension, character and setting
Elaboration: Discussing what is learnt about a character through dialogue such as their likes, dislikes or personal qualities

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Compare how authors and illustrators make literary texts exciting, moving and absorbing and hold readers’ interest by using plot tension, character and setting
Elaboration: Identifying moments in the plot where characters are faced with choices, and commenting on how the author makes the reader care about their decisions and the consequences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Compare how authors and illustrators make literary texts exciting, moving and absorbing and hold readers’ interest by using plot tension, character and setting
Elaboration: Identifying how illustrations contribute to the meaning of stories by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore the use of literary devices and deliberate wordplay, including grammar, in prose and poetry, and the ways that they shape meaning
Elaboration: Defining neologisms and puns, and identifying how they are used by authors to create a sense of freshness, originality and playfulness

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore the use of literary devices and deliberate wordplay, including grammar, in prose and poetry, and the ways that they shape meaning
Elaboration: Discussing poetic language, including adjectives that engage readers emotionally and bring the poet’s subject matter to life

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore the use of literary devices and deliberate wordplay, including grammar, in prose and poetry, and the ways that they shape meaning
Elaboration: Exploring emotive language in texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create texts by developing storylines, characters and settings, and using language features from literary texts they have encountered and from their own experiences
Elaboration: Creating texts using a range of sentence types, including dialogue and literary devices

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to gather information in order to carry out tasks, contribute to discussions, acknowledge another opinion, link a response to the text or topic, and share and extend ideas and information
Elaboration: Making notes about a task, asking questions to clarify or follow up information, and seeking assistance if required

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to gather information in order to carry out tasks, contribute to discussions, acknowledge another opinion, link a response to the text or topic, and share and extend ideas and information
Elaboration: Developing speaking and listening behaviours, including acknowledging and extending others’ contributions, and presenting ideas and opinions clearly and coherently

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver structured spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Reporting on a topic in an organised manner, providing relevant facts and descriptive detail to support audience understanding, and using references to reliable sources to support claims

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver structured spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Exploring the effects of changing tone, volume, pitch and pace in formal and informal contexts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver structured spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Rehearsing a presentation with a peer and sharing feedback about tone, pace, pitch and volume appropriate for audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use and apply phonological and morphological knowledge to read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter combinations, including a variety of vowel sounds and known prefixes and suffixes
Elaboration: Recognising unstressed vowels in multisyllabic words and how these vowel sounds are written, for example ‘builder’ and ‘animal’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use and apply phonological and morphological knowledge to read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter combinations, including a variety of vowel sounds and known prefixes and suffixes
Elaboration: Using phonemic awareness and morphological knowledge (including blending and segmenting sounds, syllables and morphemes) to read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter combinations, for example ‘straightaway’ and ‘thoughtful’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use knowledge of letter patterns, including double letters, spelling generalisations, morphological word families, word origins, and common prefixes and suffixes to spell more complex words
Elaboration: Applying generalisations for adding affixes; for example, ‘hope’ becomes ‘hoping’, ‘begin’ becomes ‘beginning’, ‘country’ becomes ‘countries’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use knowledge of letter patterns, including double letters, spelling generalisations, morphological word families, word origins, and common prefixes and suffixes to spell more complex words
Elaboration: Building morphemic word families and exploring word origins, for example ‘tricycle’, ‘tripod’ and ‘triangle’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read and write high-frequency words including homophones and know how to use context to identify correct spelling
Elaboration: Recognising that contextual and syntactical clues can be used to determine the use of homophones, for example ‘We grow wheat on our farm.’ and ‘The train trip will take about an hour.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read different types of texts, integrating phonic, semantic and grammatical knowledge to read accurately and fluently for meaning, re-reading and self-correcting when needed
Elaboration: Reading increasingly complex texts using established word identification strategies, knowledge of the topic and understanding of text structure and language features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Compare how texts from different times, with similar purposes and audiences, depict ideas or events
Elaboration: Viewing documentaries and news footage from different periods and comparing the purpose and audience, for example coverage of major sporting events

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Compare how texts from different times, with similar purposes and audiences, depict ideas or events
Elaboration: Comparing the texts used to communicate between family members, noting similarities and differences as a result of changing technology

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the characteristic features used in different types of texts to meet the purpose and audience of the text
Elaboration: Identifying how authors use language to create imaginary worlds

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the characteristic features used in different types of texts to meet the purpose and audience of the text
Elaboration: Identifying how authors use techniques, such as headings, italics and bold text, to support readers or viewers to navigate specific texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the characteristic features used in different types of texts to meet the purpose and audience of the text
Elaboration: Identifying visual features such as images and layout used in informative texts to complement, add to or shape understanding of a topic

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to expand topic knowledge and ideas, and begin to evaluate texts to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Making connections between information in print, images and sound

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to expand topic knowledge and ideas, and begin to evaluate texts to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Reading or listening for key topic-specific vocabulary words to build understanding

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to expand topic knowledge and ideas, and begin to evaluate texts to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Reading or listening to interpret the main idea and supporting ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to expand topic knowledge and ideas, and begin to evaluate texts to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Identifying evidence and reasoning used by authors to support points or arguments

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to expand topic knowledge and ideas, and begin to evaluate texts to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Applying self-monitoring strategies such as re-reading, pausing and questioning, and self-correction strategies such as confirming and crosschecking

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to expand topic knowledge and ideas, and begin to evaluate texts to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Connecting the use of colours, images, symbols and patterns in texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to expand topic knowledge and ideas, and begin to evaluate texts to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Evaluating an author’s use of evidence to support arguments

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, using relevant, linked ideas for a range of audiences and using multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Using research to gather ideas for writing and integrating information from a range of sources, which may include those found online

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, using relevant, linked ideas for a range of audiences and using multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Selecting text structure and planning how to group ideas into paragraphs to sequence content

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, using relevant, linked ideas for a range of audiences and using multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Using topic-specific, precise and varied vocabulary

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, using relevant, linked ideas for a range of audiences and using multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Choosing a variety of appropriate words and phrases, including descriptive words and some technical vocabulary, to communicate meaning accurately

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, using relevant, linked ideas for a range of audiences and using multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Using grammatical features, including different types of verb groups, noun groups and adverb groups/phrases, for effective descriptions and details according to purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read and edit texts for meaning by adding, deleting or moving words or word groups to improve content and structure
Elaboration: Collaborating with a peer to edit literary texts by sharing feedback about choices made to develop storylines, characters and settings

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read and edit texts for meaning by adding, deleting or moving words or word groups to improve content and structure
Elaboration: Revising written texts to improve the selection of words used to connect ideas and to improve the cohesion of the text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write words using clearly formed joined letters, with developing fluency and automaticity
Elaboration: Content description does not require elaboration.
